Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Distributed Biological Observatory (DBO)-A Change Detection Array in the Pacific Arctic Region
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Arctic is changing. The Distributed Biological Observatory studies these changes in the northern Bering and Chukchi seas. Investigators sample locations that are biologically important in U.S. territorial waters. These locations have been sampled annually since 2010. Other investigators also sample the same locations. As a result, the locations are sampled multiple times a year. Data are collected on environmental conditions including water column and sea floor animals that are food for whales, seals, and birds. Data are shared internationally. The project contributes to the U.S. National Ocean Policy and Interagency Arctic Research Policy Committee 5-year plan. The data will be of value to U.S. and international science and management agencies, private industry, and local communities as they try to understand changes to the environment. The project supports three graduate students.

The observational plan includes standard hydrographic and biological measurements along five transect lines located in the northern Bering and Chukchi Seas. These sampling locations are arrayed south-to-north and reflect a gradient of seasonal sea ice change and seawater warming. The investigators chose these 5 regions because they are zones of high biological productivity and biodiversity. Results so far indicate a freshening and warming of Pacific seawater which transits northward over the spring to fall season. These changes have impacted prey for larger marine mammals and seabirds. Satellite observations are also used to evaluate seasonal changes in sea ice concentration, surface seawater temperature, and chlorophyll concentration. The biological measurements focus on lower trophic levels and shipboard surveys of upper trophic level organisms. This research will increase our understanding of the impact of key environmental forcing parameters on biological change in the system. The collection of key prey-predator biological data along with physical and chemical measurements will allow for analyses and ecosystem modeling which will promote better understanding of Arctic environmental changes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Arctic ecosystem is changing with warming seawater and reduced sea ice cover. The Distributed Biological Observatory (DBO) studies these changes in the northern Bering and Chukchi seas, which are in the United States Exclusive Economic Zone. The scientists funded through this project sampled locations that are biologically important for supporting the food web. These locations have been sampled annually since 2010, with support from the National Science Foundation beginning in 2012.  Other national and international investigators also sampled the same locations for standard measurements, resulting in multiple data collections in a year. Data are collected on environmental conditions, including water column conditions, plankton, and sea floor animals that are food for whales, seals, and birds and these data have been shared with collaborators and open data archive sites. This scientific collaboration has allowed for development of a seasonal and interannual time series record that allow us to track status and change in the marine ecosystem components. The project contributes to the U.S. National Ocean Policy and Interagency Arctic Research Policy Committee 5-year plan. The data is of value to U.S. and international science and management agencies, private industry, and local communities as they try to understand changes to the environment. The project supported early career scientists, technicians, and the lead scientists for both field and laboratory work.

The observational plan included standard hydrographic and biological measurements under this support occurred along five transect lines located in the northern Bering and Chukchi Seas. These sampling locations that are arrayed south-to-north to reflect a gradient of seasonal sea ice change and seawater warming, including DBO 1 (SLIP)-south of St. Lawrence Island (SLI), DBO2 (Chirikov)-north of SLI, DBO3 (southern Chukchi Sea), DBO4-NE Chukchi Sea, and DBO5-Barrow Canyon. An additional 3 DBO transects were also added to the international DBO network: DBO 6 (western Beaufort Sea), DBO7 (central Beaufort Sea), and DBO8 (eastern Beaufort Sea/Cape Bathurst) through collaborative studies. The investigators of this 2017-2019 DBO project focused on the core five DBO1-5 regions because they are in zones of high biological productivity and biodiversity. Recent results show a major reduction in sea ice coverage in the northern Bering Sea, particularly in the 2018-2019 period in the northern Bering Sea resulting from the enhanced warming of Pacific seawater transiting through the region during this period. These changes have impacted both water column and benthic prey for larger marine mammals and seabirds. Satellite observations were also used to evaluate changing seasonal sea ice concentrations, warming surface seawater temperatures, and variable chlorophyll concentration interannually. The biological measurements focused on lower trophic level prey, such as clams, crustaceans and worms and shipboard surveys of upper trophic level predators, such as whales and walrus. Benthic video images are available for public access at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QGvJm1VjGrk. Notably, there has been a contraction of the biomass of benthic prey northward in the southern 3 DBO sites related to changing food production, current speed that influence sediment type, and warming seawater. Similarly, we observed more northward migration of subarctic whales, such as humpback and killer whales. This research has increased our understanding of the impact of key environmental forcing parameters on biological change in the system. The collection of key prey-predator biological data along with physical and chemical measurements can be used for future analyses and development of ecosystem modeling which will promote better understanding of Arctic environmental changes. Further information on the DBO can be found on the new DBO website at https://dbo.cbl.umces.edu/.
